newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan February gold imports up 22.57 pct y/y.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan February gold imports up 22.57 pct y/y.

text.p: Taiwan's imports of gold bars, coins and plate rose 22.57 percent to 9.785 tonnes in February from 7.983 tonnes a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said on Friday.
Traders attributed the February import jump to falling world gold prices and a domestic economic recovery.

Taiwan March gold imports were expected to fall due to rising international gold prices and a slowing of local buying interest in the wake of the mid-February Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, typically a period of high demand, dealers said.
Taiwan gold dealers said imports from South Korea were mainly from transshipments.
Many major Korean firms made speculative gold transshipments before the South Korean government began cracking down on the practice in July 1996.

Typically, South Korean bullion houses imported gold on 90- to 120-day deferred payments, then immediately exported the gold at a slight discount and put the proceeds in high-interest money market instruments that more than made up for the discounts.
Significant profits could be made by exploiting the gap between South Korea's interest rates and London's Interbank Offered Rate and re-export tax breaks.
But on July 1, Seoul shortened the deferred payment period to a maximum of 30 days, instantly chilling what had been a booming transshipment business.
Taiwan traders said some scattered trading still existed in South Korea, but on a much smaller scale.
The ministry said Taiwan's gold exports in February remained modest at 0.284 tonnes, up from 0.375 tonnes in February 1995.
